div.ab:
The Book did not speak, but was silent.
He laughed, as if at a coarse joke,
Because the book had no value for him
and he threw it down and was charged.
Thus reading and writing were thought
by this people to be fantastical.

22. Yet formerly in houses of the Region
were hanging a large number of ropes
in various colors, made of cotton,
and full of knots of different shapes.
Their number allowed them to discern
the history of their country in earlier times.
and there were People appointed for this purpose,
who knew how to interpret the sense of these knots.
right-middleWith ropes of cotton in different colors, full of knots, they recorded their annals, that is, their yearly histories.

23. In short, all over the World,
among all kinds of Peoples (there is no mistaking it)
the nature of Colors, their power and qualities, prevails,
as well as its effects and meanings.
Though it is quite different among the Eastern Javanese,
for there it is believed that white means
and is a reminder of sorrow, while black is a sign
of all that can bring pleasure and joy.
Color has power and effects over everything.
right-middleAmong the Javanese, white is a sign of sorrow, and black, of joy.

24. When we speak of drawing,
we have not forgotten the Art of Letters.
Here is [enclosed] writing in the power of color.
However, Euphranor’s Book of Color has failed us,
destroyed by the instability of time.
Indeed, the Book of the secrets of Color
of this ingenious and famous ancient painter,
was stolen from us by jealous antiquity.
right-middleEuphranor, an ancient Painter, write about Colors.

25. Finally, what more beautiful Colors the Lord
has wished to grant, and so generously given us
in noble, rare and precious stones!
But it goes beyond human thought
to imagine, or consider in one’s heart,
with what beautiful colors, in the afterlife,
the absolutely pure and clear
Heaven, above nature, shall glow.
right-middleOn the splendor of stones. right-middleOn the beauty of the new Jerusalem.

div.ab:
26. Of purest Gold, and transparent glass,
the extraordinary stones of Sardius and Jasper,
Chrysolite, Hyacinth, Topaz,
Amethyst, Emerald, Chrysoprase,
And other magnificent pure colors,
John describes the sweet domain of the Sky.
Therefore we leave the Color here,
high above the earth, in its heavenly dignity.
right-middleHere, in the end, the colors are taken to heaven.

ab.b: End of the origin, nature, etc. of Color
